title: Enterprise Crypto Custody
summary: This course talks about the requirements, technology, and also some of the providers that provide crypto custody to Enterprises

topics.title: Intoduction
topics.details:
Enterprise stores crypto in a variety of ways, depending on the specific requirements of the organization. Some common methods include:

1. **Cold storage**: This involves storing the crypto offline, on a hardware wallet or paper wallet, to protect it from hacking and other online threats.

2. **Multi-sig wallets**: This involves using multiple keys to access the crypto, with each key held by a different person or department, to increase security and control.

3. **Custodial services**: This involves using a third-party service provider to securely store and manage the crypto on behalf of the enterprise.

4. **Hardware Security Modules**: This is a specialized, tamper-resistant hardware that stores the cryptographic keys used to access the crypto.

5. **A multiparty computation (MPC) wallet**: This technology enables multiple parties to jointly perform computations on sensitive data without revealing it to any of the parties involved.

In this course we will look at various ways enterprises can store their crypto and some of the most important requirements that enterprises have.

topics.title: Fireblocks
topics.details: Fireblocks is the digital asset storage, transfer, and issuance platform you can trust. With pioneering multi-layer security, financial institutions can easily enter the digital asset space and scale their services with speed and confidence. Fireblocks offers enterprise-grade wallet security, the industry’s only institutional digital asset transfer network, and a configurable governance framework to set risk and operational controls. Plus, they directly connect to major exchanges, OTC desks, and liquidity providers - so you can always get the best asset prices.

explanations.details: Fireblocks has a multi-layer security system that includes MPC, Intel SGX, a Policy Engine, and a deposit address authentication network. This ensures that users’ assets are protected from cyberattacks, internal collusion, and human error.
explanations.title: Multi-Layer Security Solution

explanations.details:
The MPC-CMP protocol, created by Fireblocks, applies the idea of MPC wallets to ECDSA and EdDSA signatures on blockchains (used by all blockchains). MPC-CMP has all of the great benefits that MPC-GG18 has, plus it helps with new operational challenges like regulations, security, and speed. In terms of speed, the quickest transaction signing speeds for digital assets are currently provided by MPC-CMP. Furthermore, this new algorithm has introduced a new security feature that automatically refreshes MPC key shares in minutes-long intervals. That means a malicious actor only has a few moments to steal all the key shards before the shares are refreshed, effectively adding a new layer of protection to our multi-layered crypto security system. In specific environments with stringent regulations regarding key storage, it may not be possible to use a standard MPC wallet because it requires an internet connection. MPC-CMP addresses this challenge by permitting hot and cold key signing mechanisms, where at least one key share is stored offline on an air-gapped device. To add an extra layer of security even in the event that one of the physical data centers is compromised, Fireblocks gives users a variety of choices for distributing the cryptographic MPC shares:

- Distribution across multiple tier-1 cloud providers (Microsoft Azure and IBM Cloud) 
- Distribution across several on-prem datacenters 
- Hybrid (on-prem data centers and cloud providers (such as Microsoft Azure) are used simultaneously)

As institutions have entered the ecosystem, new requirements for the digital asset area have emerged. MPC-CMP was created to fulfill these requirements and is future-proof.
explanations.title: Layer-1: MPC + Multi-Cloud

explanations.details: Intel SGX is a hardware-level security feature that creates an isolated area within a system, similar to an HSM (hardware security module) from the operating system. Its purpose is to protect cryptographic material, algorithms, and the execution of sensitive code from insiders (such as rogue administrators) and hackers. SGX enclaves are a great way to distribute private keys with a very high level of security. By using them on a minimum of 3-5 machines, each on a separate network, you can be sure that your keys will be safe. The keys are kept in SGX, so even if malware or a hacker gains access to the server's operating system, they cannot be removed because the memory and the data in the SGX enclave are encrypted. SGX is used to store API keys in order to keep them secure from potential hackers. Exchange credentials are stored in TEEs, or Trusted Execution Environments so that not even Fireblocks employees can retrieve the information.
explanations.title: Layer-2: SGX (Software Guard Extension)

explanations.details: The Fireblocks Policy Engine is the next step for digital asset security, allowing organizations to set up specific approval policies for every transaction. With the Policy Engine, users can configure a list of rules that determine how transactions are handled and approved. For example, a rule can block, approve, or require additional signers for a transaction based on filters such as source, destination, asset, and amount. Fireblocks has implemented SGX security measures in order to protect the Policy Engine. This involves distributing policy verification among several MPC servers. In addition, the policy rules are signed by a quorum of administrators and encrypted within SGX. By taking these measures, Fireblocks prevents both hackers and insiders (such as IT administrators) from modifying the implemented rules or the logic of the policy engine.
explanations.title: Layer-3: Policy Engine

explanations.details: In order to prevent the entire private key from being taken from a single device in the event that a hacker or insider penetrates the device, the MPC wallet is used to distribute the private key into shares using a threshold signature across multiple servers or devices. The hardware isolation of each individual key share protects them from being extracted by an attacker, even if they control the machine. This way, no single private key share can be compromised. This is done using Intel SGX. Device distribution across many physical data centers is done to reduce physical attacks. Verification of counterparties' deposit addresses over secure channels that are resistant to host-based attacks is done to remove human error on deposit addresses. The final step involves separating responsibilities across various corporate areas and enforcing policies/approval processes.

questions.content: Why is a Multi-Layer Security Solution needed for crypto custody?
questions.explanation: A multi-layer solution ensures higher safety and provides layers of protection against hackers.

choices.content: Multiple defensive mechanisms in place to protect data
Protects crypto from offline and online threats

questions.content: What makes Fireblock wallets different from other MPC wallets?
questions.explanation: A Fireblock wallet provides hardware isolation in form of Intel SGX. MPC-CMP wallet is also faster and more secure as compared to the general MPC wallet.

choices.content: Provides hardware isolation of private keys
MPC-CMP used in FIreblock wallet is faster and more secure
Wallets are implemented using smart contracts

questions.content: How is MPC-CMP different from a general MPC wallet?
questions.explanation: MPC-CMP is faster and more secure than a general MPC wallet. It provides hardware isolation. Furthermore, it permits both hot and cold signing mechanisms.

choices.content: It does not eliminate single point of compromise
It is faster and more secure than a general MPC wallet
Permits both hot and cold signing mechanisms
